ygData.subject: Re: HyperNEAT and Hidden Nodes?
ygData.msgSnippet: ... me ... Wesley, the paper is talking about adding a hidden node to the CPPN, not to the substrate.  The substrate, as you mention, has no hidden nodes. You

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "tansey4" <tansey4@...> wrote:
>
> I just fini=
shed reading "Generating Large-Scale Neural Networks
> Through Discovering =
Geometric Regularities" and I had a couple of
> quick questions.
> 
> 1) Th=
e paper says that in the HyperNEAT experiments, there was a 3%
> chance of =
adding a hidden node.  How exactly does this work? Doesn't
> the CPPN need =
to know of a hidden layer at the start?  It looks to 
me
> like there is on=
ly an input/source layer and an output/target layer
> that's being mapped i=
n the state-space sandwich.
> 

Wesley, the paper is talking about adding a=
 hidden node to the CPPN, 
not to the substrate.  The substrate, as you men=
tion, has no hidden 
nodes.

You can however create a substrate with hidden=
 nodes if you want.  We 
already have some experiments running here with hi=
dden nodes with 
good results.  There are several ways to add hidden nodes,=
 e.g. you 
could embed them into a 3D or 2D substrate structure.  There are=
 
other options as well.

> 2) Why were tests run against P-NEAT and not ag=
ainst regular NEAT? 
Was
> it just for saving computational resources?
> 

=
The problem is that HyperNEAT optimizes in this problem only the 
direct li=
nks from inputs to outputs.  We wanted 
to compare it to a system with the =
equivalent optimization problem, 
i.e. one with exactly the same number of =
dimensions (connections) to 
optimize in the phenotype.  With regular NEAT,=
 the number of 
dimensions would vary.

Contrary to the usual case with reg=
ular NEAT, in this problem adding 
structure could be a liability because o=
f the enormous number of 
connections in the initial population.  It is alr=
eady in a massive 
>10,000 dimensional space just with the zero-hidden-node=
 starter 
population, so in fact in this case, NEAT will likely do no bette=
r 
than P-NEAT and probably worse.

However, our main motivation for using =
P-NEAT was simply to ensure 
that the comparison was between two systems th=
at optimized exactly 
the same set of connections.

ken

> 
> I loved the p=
aper though overall.  It's really exciting and 
hopefully
> I'll be able to=
 use it in a project I'm planning on starting.
> 
> Thanks,
> Wesley
>
